subject: Philosophy
title: The Drowning Child
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: The Drowning Child.

hook.text: You walk past a pond. A child is drowning. You can easily save them. Are you morally required to act?

buildup.text: Almost everyone says yes. Letting the child die when you can help is monstrous.

discovery.text: Peter Singer then asks: children die daily from preventable causes. Why don't we feel the same urgency?

twist.text: Distance shouldn't matter morally. A child in another country is equally real and equally dying.

climax.text: Singer argues we're morally obligated to give until it hurts. Few actually do ‚Äî and that's the dilemma.

punchline.text: The child in the pond is everywhere.

quiz.question: What is Singer's main argument in the drowning child thought experiment?
options: Distance shouldn't change our moral obligations
We should only help people nearby
